metadata.title: Recent advances in nano‐materials for packaging of electronic devices

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
As the processing scale of current semiconductor technology is gradually lower than 100 nm, semiconductor has entered the era of nanotechnology. Over time, the semiconductor industry’s process is shrinking from 65 to 45 nm and even to 10 nm [1, 2]. However, in large-scale integrated circuits, the physical size of the metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) gradually reaches the limit, which means Moore’s law facing great challenges. Although it is difficult to reduce the size of COMS in chips, industry is still trying to integrate chips for functional purposes [3], such as micro-electro-mechanical system (MEMS), optoelectronic devices, chemical or biological sensors and other sensing sensors [4–7]. The development of the chip industry is driven by multiple factors, such as functional requirements, cost, size and consumers’ preference for the appearance of functional chips. Those directions are called “More than Moore’s law”, “beyond Moore’s law” and “new devices”. “More than Moore’s law” is a way to continue down the Moore’s law path to reduce the package size,while “Beyond Moore’s law” is to find a new way in the previously untapped part of Moore’s law’s evolution,and
“New devices” is to develop novel devices to overcome the physical limitations of silicon-based CMOS [8–10].
Actually, packaging is the final manufacturing process that transforms semiconductor devices into functional electronic products required by end users. It not only provides functions such as electrical signal connection, signal transmission and power control, but also provides heat dissipation and mechanical protection to improve chip reliability [11]. Packaging technology not only restricts the size, shape and weight of chips, but also determines the chip reliability [12, 13]. In the rapidly changing environment of current technology, packaging technology is both a pioneer and a constraint of the semiconductor market. Overall, design concepts, packaging structures, advanced electronic materials, manufacturing processes, equipment, and systems integration technologies are changing and innovating rapidly [14, 15], which will bring new impetus to the development of the semiconductor industry.
Materials are the core of electronic packaging technology. Driven by “More than Moore’s law” and “beyond Moore’s law”, the demand for packaging materials has been expanded from simple traditional packaging technology to the next generation of new high-density packaging, such as System in Package (SiP), Wafer Level Packaging, Integrated Passive Device (IPD), Through Silicon Via (TSV), Die & Wafer Stacking, 3 Dimension Packaging, RF devices, MEMS devices and physical, chemical and biological sensors [16, * Peng He hithepeng@hit.edu.cn
1 State Key Laboratory of Advanced Welding and Joining, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China
1 3
17]. However, the currently used materials cannot meet the requirements for next-generation requirement, especially for complex SiP chips. Due to the demanding requirements of today’s integrated circuits such as large number of wireless hot spots, extremely high current density, and mechanical pressure acting on a very thin chip, traditional packaging materials’ electrical properties, thermal properties and mechanical properties often cannot meet the needs of continuously developing integrated circuits.
Nanomaterials and nanotechnology are expected to provide more solutions for future packaging challenges and bottlenecks [18]. According to the latest literature, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [19], nanowires [20, 21], and nanoparticles [22] have shown unique electrical, thermal, and mechanical properties that are orders of magnitude superior to some of the materials currently used. For example, carbon nanotubes and metal nanowires can theoretically withstand a maximum current density about 1000 times greater than copper; graphene resistivity can reach about 10−6 Ω cm, which are much smaller than traditional gold, copper, silver and other metal resistance [23, 24]. So how to utilize the unique physical properties of nanomaterials to apply in the next generation of packaging and materials processing is currently a very important question for electronic packaging.

sections.heading: 2 Advanced electronic materials and nano interconnection
2.1 Packaging requirements
sections.text:
In terms of size and weight, 3D design replaces singlechip packaging to reduce device size and make weight lighter. After more than 50 years of rapid development, electronic packaging devices have made rapid progress from the low-density dual inline-pin packaging invented in 1970s to the high-density 3D system packaging in 2010s. Packaging pins and electrical integration have achieved rapid development. [25–27]. The silicon packaging efficiency (SPE) of the chip is defined as the ratio of the area of the Si chip to the overall Packaging area. In the 70s and 80s, SPE of chip is only 10–25%, and by the 1990s due to the advantage of using multiple chip integration packaging, SPE reach 50–70%. At the beginning of this century, in view of the development of embedded passive components and modules stacked technology, SPE of chip is increased to 70–90%, while in recent years scientists will expect to achieve 3D packaging technology and SPE of chip is expected to achieve 100% as shown in Fig. 1
1 3
[28]. As the performance and power consumption of the developed IC devices are improved, the heat dissipation and robust solder joints cannot be avoided. Actually, all the heat of the electronic devices is generated by electrical joule principle through the metallic interconnect. We need find out the higher conductivity of the micro and nano interconnect, especially high performance of the novel and nano-materials should not be ignored [29]. Therefore, at present, the prior technical problems of electronic packaging are to be issued:
(1) Thermal management (2) Robust interconnection (3) High I/O density (4) Anti-electromagnetic interference (5) Packaging feasibility and high reliability

sections.heading: 2.2 Carbon nanotubes (CNTs)
sections.text:
In order to reduce the heat dissipation of devices, carbon nanotubes have good mechanical properties. The tensile strength of CNTs reaches 50–200 GPa, which is 100 times that of steel, but the density is only 1/6 of that of steel and at least one order of magnitude higher than that of conventional graphite fiber; its elastic modulus is up to 1 TPa, which is equivalent to that of diamond and about five times of steel. The tensile strength of single-walled carbon nanotubes with ideal structure is about 800 GPa [30]. Although the structure of carbon nanotubes is similar to polymer materials, it is much more stable than that of polymer materials. Carbon nanotubes are the materials with the highest specific strength that can be prepared at present. If other engineering materials are used as matrix and carbon nanotubes are made into composite materials, the composite materials can show good strength, elasticity, fatigue resistance and isotropy, and the properties of the composite materials can be greatly improved.
Carbon nanotube-polymer composites are also widely used in electronic packaging [31]. Researchers used chemical solvents, ultrasonic dispersion and alternating electric field methods [31–33] to fully disperse carbon nanotubes in composite materials, so as to improve mechanical properties such as young’s modulus [34]. Carbon nanotubes were later found to be more controllable in micron carbon fibers [35]. It is reported that carbon nanotubes can be added to silver-based conductive adhesives to improve their electrical, thermal and reliability [36]. Strong acid etching on the surface of carbon nanotubes can strengthen the connection with the surface of alumina ceramic materials to enhance the mechanical properties of the overall composite materials [37]. In wearable microsystems, CNTs mixed with carbon black materials in PDMS can be made into flexible electrodes with low resistance (maximum 80% tensile rate) [38],
but the orientation of CNTs is difficult to control because of the buckling or agglomeration of CNTs caused by polymer composites under capillary forces [39].
Compatibility of carbon nanotubes with metal-based materials is also an important application. For example the random distribution of CNTs in copper solder joints can reduce the harm of electromigration [40], and CNT has a negative thermal expansion coefficient effect, which can reduce the failure risk of solder joint due to thermal expansion and cold shrinkage heat [41]. Metal electrodes with high toughness can be prepared by nucleation and growth of Ag on CNT surface and used on flexible substrate [42]. The printed Ag–CNT composite electrode can be used as a filler for contact coating and TSV [43], as shown in Fig. 2. In addition, the addition of aligned carbon nanotubes to Sn solder increases tensile strength by 30–50% and reliability life by 40%, as well as wettability. Figure 3 shows the application of Cu–CNT nanomaterial composite in TSV. First vertically oriented carbon nanotubes are grown in the substrate, and then on the surface electroplating Cu, finally can be used in TSV device, in order to achieve 10−6 Ω cm [44].

sections.heading: 2.3 Nano‑solder
sections.text:
In the process of electronic package interconnection, leadfree Sn-based solder is the common connecting material. However, lead-free Sn-based solder need higher reflow temperature due to its high melting point (210–240 °C), which increased the energy consumption in the process of electronics assembly and greatly reduces the reliability of the device. Nanoscale lead-free solder has thermodynamic size effect and its melting point can be reduce much lower than that of bulk materials. Nowadays, the commonly used low-melting lead-free solders are all based on Sn-58Bi and Sn-52In eutectic alloys, and some another alloy elements are added to them. The low temperature solders of these two systems are prone to dendrite segregation and coarse microstructure during solidification. And the stress imbalance often leads to solder joint stripping, and their reliability is seriously insufficient compared with the commonly used SnAgCu solders. In addition, In is also very expensive (similar in price to Ag) [45].
The biggest advantage of the nanosacle lead-free solder is low melting point, so the high melting point solder can be formed at low temperature [46]. When the nano solder is less than a certain size, melting point solder falls sharply. When the nanometer size solder is downing to 10–12 nm, its melting point close to SnPb eutectic solder melting point (180 °C); and when the size is near to 6–7 nm, its melting point have fallen to below 140 °C [47]. Super cooling degree is an important factor affecting the microstructure of solder joints after welding [48]. Under the same cooling
1 3
conditions, the nanoscale solder can achieve better morphology and property than the microscale solder [49].
The preparation method plays a key role in the research, development and application of nanomaterials. Up till now, the main methods that can be applied to the preparation of nano-solder are mechanical alloy method [50], arc discharge method [51], physical vapor deposition method [69], liquid phase chemical reduction method [52, 53], etc. The first two methods have low cost and simple process, but the obtained powder size is not uniform, which means easy to agglomerate and easy to introduce impurities. The physical vapor deposition method has high reaction speed and high crystallinity, but the reaction condition is harsh and needs to be carried out in a vacuum environment. So far, the most widely studied method is liquid phase chemical reduction method, which is to prepare metal nanoparticles through the REDOX reaction between ions in the liquid phase. The process is simple, the equipment investment is small, the reaction is easy to control and the size is small and uniform.
The surface energy of nanometer solder is too high so that the agglomeration often occurs in the storage process. Due to the small size effect of nanoparticles, even small differences
can cause drastic changes in the melting point of particles. The newly prepared nanoparticles were well dispersed and some particles were agglomerated after being stored at room temperature for 40 days [54]. When the nanometer solder is prepared, it will be mixed with flux/paste to form a nanometer solder paste, which can be applied to the interconnection of devices. Although many research institutions have been able to prepare low melting point of the nano lead-free solder, but so far, no one in the true sense of the nano lead-free solder paste has been prepared. The main reason is that these solder paste cannot form a complete solder joint without voids and pores.
On the other hand, the surfactant usually decomposes at a high temperature [45]. In the welding process, the phenomenon that the nanometer solder has melted but the surfactant has not decomposed will occur, thus hindering the fusion of metal particles. Although the nano solder already melt in 199 °C, but its surface organic composition just complete decomposition in above 250 °C, it brought difficulties to the application of nano solder paste. Therefore, the development of surfactants that decompose rapidly at the right temperature is crucial for the further development of nano-solders.
1 3

sections.heading: 2.4 Nano‑silver
sections.text:
Through screen printing and sintering of nano-metal particles in the suspension solvent [55, 56], the surface electrical interconnection between the plate layer and the packaging layer can be realized. At present, ink-jet printing technology is widely used to print the metal conductive materials on the flexible polymer-based laminates [57]. Electrical properties are formed through the sintering of nanoparticles, and the sintering processes can be achieved through laser irradiation, oven heating, surface plasmon-based source effect, etc. [58–61]. Traditionally, temperature is an important factor in sintering of metal nanoparticles, so the sintering connection can only occur when the temperature is high enough. Figure 3 shows the gradual decrease of the resistivity of silver nanoparticle film with the increase of sintering temperature [62]. However, due to the long baking time of flexible substrate, the resistivity of sintering at 250 °C increased slightly. Table 1 summarizes the common names of polymer flexible
substrate materials and their glass transition temperature [63]. Generally, flexible substrate materials with low thermal stability and glass transition temperature are preferred. After sintering, the substrate is easily bent, which will decrease the precision and quality of printed electronic patterns.
1 3
On the other hand, chemical sintering is a method of printing metal patterns by adding a chemical agent along with the nanoparticles. It has the advantage to be done at room temperature. Since the volatilization of solvent materials and the aggregation of nanoparticles are very slow in the process of hot sintering [64], this method can rapidly complete sintering at room temperature and improve the electrical conductivity. As shown in Fig. 4, at the beginning of chemical sintering, the dispersant on the silver nanoparticles dissolves or desorbs on the reagent, resulting the silver nanoparticles contacting to form a conductive path [65, 66]. Peng et al. bond Ag nanoparticles to the surface of PVP by C–O–Ag chemical bond in silver nano-ink, making the surface of Ag particles firmly coated on the PVP film. When the KCl reagent was added, the C–O–Ag bond was broken due to the strong interaction between Ag+ and Cl− ions, and the C–O bond became C=O bond, thus the surface of Ag particles was separated from the PVP membrane.
Microwave radiation is widely used in sintering of metal and ceramic materials, and it has the advantages of fast heating rate and high sintering efficiency [67]. In the sintering process, the interaction between silver nanoparticles and microwave radiation generates heat to achieve the purpose of sintering. Because the absorbance of the polymer matrix to microwave radiation is almost zero, the substrate temperature is always lower than the glass transition temperature (Tg) during the sintering process. When silver nanoparticles are coated with dispersant, each particle interacts with microwave radiation respectively, so the microwave penetration depth of silver nanowires is greater than that of silver itself [68]. In addition, microwave is also suitable for sintering nano silver antenna structure. The antennas help absorb microwaves, which speed up the sintering of nanoparticles. Perelaer et al. study a combination of microwave radiation and plasma sintering method which is used to connect RFID, after 1 s sintering, its low resistance rate could reach 5.9 × 10−6 Ω cm [69].
Infrared irradiation sintering makes use of the infrared absorption difference between silver and polymer to rapidly sinter the desired nano silver pattern in a few seconds. Figure 5 shows the microwave and infrared irradiation for nanosilver sintering. The selection of infrared wavelength is the
key factor affecting the quality of infrared sintering. In order to ensure that the silver can absorb most of the energy, the substrate should have good infrared transmission ability to prevent the substrate from bending due to overheating. Figure 5b shows the transmission spectra of PET, PEN and Ag. It can be seen from the figure that the near-infrared region is large enough to meet the requirements. Ink-jet printing scheme of infrared sintered silver nanocircuit is shown in Fig. 5c. Parameters such as irradiation distance, lamp power, exposure time and position of reflector will affect sintering quality [70]. In addition, Park et al. used infrared radiation for large volume of nano silver pattern. From the substrate to 50 mm, under the condition of infrared lamp power 1000 w, only in 1.08 s time they had a high conductive printing electronic product, its resistance to 0.34 Ω/£ [71].
Recently, more and more attention has been paid to the application of micro-nano mixed materials. Peng et al. used silver nanoparticles and nanowires mixed solder to bond copper wires under non-pressure and low-temperature sintering conditions, resulting in joints with high strength and fracture energy. They found that adding 20% (volume) of silver nanowires increased the strength of low-temperature sintered (60–150 °C) joints by 50 to 80 percent. Because adding silver nanowires to the silver nanoparticle solder paste creates a micro-nano mixture similar to that of fiberreinforced composites, through which plastic deformation occurs and cracks are inhibited. [72].
Among the above sintering methods, chemical sintering is the most important one with simple sintering process and easy to obtain reagents. However, the reaction reagents and reaction products will remain in the conductive body, thus reducing their conductivity. In the process of microwave sintering, local overheating of solder joint often occurs, which limits the application of large-size samples. Infrared irradiation sintering involves many parameters, which are difficult to adjust. Besides the above sintering methods, laser sintering, pulse light sintering (IPL), plasma sintering and other methods have also been successfully applied in the sintering process of nano silver circuits. In order to select an appropriate sintering method, different nanoparticles, sintering methods and the resistivity after sintering in recent years are shown in Table 2.
1 3
The resistivity of ink-jet printed silver nano patterns is very close to that of traditional metallic silver. In addition, in terms of conductive stability, silver nano pattern has the ability to resist chemical corrosion, oxidation and mechanical damage by coating passivation layer. The electronic devices with nano-silver pattern can still maintain stable electrical conductivity after thousands of bending, which lays a good foundation for the application of ink-jet printing electronics [73]. However, there is still room for improvement in inkjet electronics. For example, the cost of printed electronics can be reduced, and the mechanical properties need to be further explored. With the progress of materials, technology and equipment, inkjet printing technology will have more indepth application in the field of printing electronics, such as full inkjet printing electronic technology, three-dimensional inkjet printing electronic technology, multi-inkjet deposition technology. In a word, inkjet printing will promote the development and promotion of printed electronic products.

sections.heading: 2.5 Nano interconnects
sections.text:
Three-dimensional wafer level packaging is one of the key technologies for the next generation, which have high performance, high encapsulation density and high reliability electronic components [74]. In order to realize the interconnection of these nano-scale integrated circuit devices, the most important method is to apply ultra-fine through-siliconvia (TSV) technology in wafer. Longitudinal connections in the aspect ratio provide the shortest interconnection length in the wafer, and because of short interconnection length, the energy loss and time delay during signal propagation are minimal, so the speed is faster. In 2006, Dr. Pradeep reported that a copper-interconnect silicon through-hole technology with a maximum aspect ratio of 15 and a minimum superfine spacing of 35 µm is studied. In order to reduce the formation of pores and ensure that the surface of pores is completely wetted by copper electrolyte, they adopt the method of improving the hydrophilicity of the surface of pores, so that the minimum diameter of copper interconnection is 15 µm and the maximum height is 400 µm [75]. Up till now,
the main research trend is electrochemical deposition of Cu and W as TSV metal filler layer materials. Meanwhile, the development roadmap of TSV solder joint diameter, spacing, depth and other parameters were summarized by the latest international semiconductor technology roadmap 2015 (ITRS 2.0: Interconnect) [76].
Moreover, the 2015 (ITRS 2.0: Interconnect) [76] also points out that the interface interconnections with characteristic sizes below 100 nm in microelectronic devices also belong to the category of nano-connection, which enables the rapid development of research related to nano-level solder [77], nano-crystal copper [78], nano-crystal nickel [79] and nano-level filler [80]. Micron-sized conductive spheres are electroplating metal onto polymer spheres of uniform shape and realize electrical intercommunication with metal electrodes through extrusion contact. It is widely used in packaging and connection of panel industry. In recent years, people have gradually realized the poor electrical performance, high resistivity, poor reliability and other problems of physical contact small balls, so some began to replace the traditional physical contact conductive balls with micron grade solder joints [81–83]. Other technologies such as micron-scale metal-coated polymer conducting columns [84], which are connected to copper using a standard reflux process, provide high-performance, low-cost solutions for wafer packaging (Fig. 6).

sections.heading: 2.6 Surface plasmonic welding
sections.text:
Surface plasmon welding is a new type interconnection and joining for recent nano metallic materials. When electromagnetic waves incident to the metal and medium interface, free electrons on the surface of the metal collective oscillation occurs. If the oscillation frequency of electrons is the consistent with the frequency of the incident light wave, resonance will produce. The resonance condition of electromagnetic field energy is efficiently into the metal surface free electrons collective vibrational energy, then a special electromagnetic model (surface plasmon polariton) has been formed [85].
A near-field electromagnetic wave propagating along the metal surface formed by the coupling of electromagnetic wave and free electron on the metal surface is called surface isonionic exciton waveguide in Fig. 7 [86]. Due to the ohmic heat effect in metals, they will gradually run out of energy and can only travel a limited distance, which is
about the order of nanometers or micrometers. The surface ionic exciters have the following basic properties: (1) the intensity of the field in the direction perpendicular to the interface decreases exponentially; (2) ability to break through the diffraction limit; (3) strong local field enhancement effect; (4) occur in the dielectric parameters
1 3
(real part) sign opposite (metal and medium) on both sides of the interface [61, 87–89].
In 2012, Brongersma et al. developed a plasmonic welding method capable of locally heating and melting the surface of nanomaterials at room temperature. The local surface plasmon resonance in the gap of nanowire junction was successfully excited by tungsten halogen lamp. This welding method is easy to operate and low cost, so it has been widely used. Especially for the preparation of flexible nanowire devices, it is an effective method to reduce the contact resistance of nanowire and thus the surface resistance [90].
Later on, Lee et al. used flashlights to conduct plasma welding on the nanowire network on the plastic substrate, and analyzed the plasma welding mechanism theoretically with the time-domain finite difference method. Finally, a flexible piezoelectric energy collector is prepared by using the nanowire network as the electrode. Their study found that the nanowires welded by plasma do not oxidize during the sintering, so the two nanowires can be securely welded together at the junction without forming an insulating layer. Thanks to the self-limitation of plasma welding, [91] even if the nanowires are treated with multiple flashes, they will not fuse (see Fig. 8). Tao et al. first self-assembled silver nanowires on the air–water interface, and then welded them into a conductive network that is easy to transport by plasma welding. Finally, the welded nanowire network was transferred to the PDMS matrix and a flexible heater was prepared [92].
This study suggests that welding on the water surface not only supports the nanowires, but also acts as a buffer against possible overheating during the welding process.
Herrmann et al. used bucket gourd molecules to assemble gold nanoparticles into a rigid polymer with a gap of 0.9 nm. After the formation of the chain, since the UV–Vis–NIR spectrum showed that the absorption wavelength of the plasma was about 800 nm, the unfocused 805 nm, 200 fs, 90 mW/ cm2 pulse laser was irradiated, which triggered the coupling between CCP resonance and laser. Due to the hot spot generated by plasma coupling, a large field enhancement is generated in the particle gap, which eventually leads to the welding of gold nanoparticles [93]. Guillermo put forward a kind of electric self-assembly process, in the process of nanometer gold rod head assembly, using low energy density of ultrafast near-infrared femtosecond laser irradiation, the particle clearance inspire efficient hot spots, molecular coupling agent is gold bar ends caused by thermal decomposition, which selectively inhibits the formation of long chain, increase the nanometer gold bar low polymers (dimer and trimer) production rate. Then a laser with high energy density is used to weld the selfassembled oligomers. High resolution HAADF-STEM images of welded oligomers show that the two nanocrystals have the same crystallographic orientation, but there is a certain difference in orientation in the welding area. Because the energy density is extremely concentrated in this area, leading to local melting at the end of the nanorods (as shown in Fig. 9) [94].

sections.heading: 3 Conclusion
sections.text:
The importance of nanoelectronics and “electro-nanotechnologies” will be significantly recognized in the future to become a crucial subject of industrial and government concerns. Although the COMS transistor technology has entered the 10 nm era with being successfully scaled to improve its performance, the interconnection performance has not been changed. Unless the revolutionary of interconnection solutions are found, the efficiency and performance of the products will increasingly be constrained, therefore, the urgency of microelectronic interconnection is obviously needed. For the overall design, 3D packaging stacking is a feasible solution, which can effectively reduce the length of the circuit path. However, 3D package interconnections still face significant challenges in terms of cost, integration methods, heat dissipation and reliability. The scientists expect that optical interconnection technology will be another possible solution. Moreover, new materials such as graphene, CNTs, nanowires provide solutions to reduce the interconnection resistivity and heat dissipation. Once graphene transistors are considered an alternative to CMOS transistors, the study of graphene as a conductor will be more extensive. In addition, the research on the adjacent transistors will be more important, because the traditional metal interconnection that cannot provide an effective communicate with adjacent transistors and improve the performance of the whole package. There are two alternative interconnection technologies: solder joint alternatives and Cu electrode alternatives. The former uses new materials such as graphene, carbon nanotubes and nanowires to replace traditional solder joints. The latter uses optical media to replace the traditional Cu metal. In general, advanced materials will make more an more outstanding contributions in the development of electronic packaging in the next 10–20 years. The main benefits and concerns of the different emerging interconnect options are shown in Table 3.

metadata.abstractText: In recent years, Moore’s law had a remarkable effect on predicting the development of semiconductor technology. As the size of devices shrinks to micro scale or nano scale, Intel’s newest 10-nm logic technology is scheduled to start product shipments before the end of 2017. Moore’s law will not die out, as the research scale reaches the atomic scale, “new devices” and new interconnection methods are urgently needed. In this paper, based on emerging interconnection requirement, the contribution to the advanced electronic packaging containing novel nano-materials, such as the carbon nanotubes, nanoparticles sintering, interconnection of nano-solder, nano-silver and surface plasma nano-welding are discussed. For the next 5–10 years, two new types of interconnect solutions are gaining attentions: solder joint alternatives and Cu electrode alternatives. The former uses new materials such as graphene, carbon nanotubes and nanowires to replace traditional solder joints. The latter uses optical media to replace the traditional Cu metal. In general, advanced materials will make more and more outstanding contributions in the development of electronic packaging in the next 10–20 years.
metadata.creator: Springer
